Description: Cypriot terracotta female figure musician with tambourine. Fragment of naked body, neck and both arms, right arm holding tambourine with traces of red paint. Typical figure type of a woman with double necklace, long flowing hair and tambourine. Cypriot clay pressed into one-piece mould. Fine pink fabric with light buff surface, with frequent fine black (volcanic?) inclusions and sparse white (limestone) and red (grog) inclusions.
Curator's comments: Produced in the workshops of Arsos during the last third of the 7th century BC (Karageorghis 1999, pl.51.4, Type VI(ii) 6, 8, 12, 13, 16 & 17, figs 41-2, pls 51.4, 52.1-3, 53.9) and probably into the 6th century BC as Gjerstad cites similar examples of tambourine musicians as parallels for his Eastern Neo-Cypriot style, that he dates between 570 and 520 BC (Gjerstad 1948, 105-7, pl.7). The Arsos workshops exported such figurines to Rhodes, Samos as well as Naukratis. See GR 1897,0401.896, 1897,0401.894 and 1900,0903.2. Karageorghis, J. 1999. ‘The coroplastic art of ancient Cyprus.V. The Cypro-Archaic Period small female figurines’. Nicosia, University of Cyprus. Gjerstad, E. 1948. 'The Swedish Cyprus Expedition. Vol. IV, Part 2, The Cypro-Geometric, Cypro-Archaic and Cypro-Classical periods'. Stockholm, The Swedish Cyprus Expedition.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (B325)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DA.017) (Phase 1)
